messages.message: Is there a way to pull the training logs via an API or located on a drive for each training sample
Or are the logs being outputted to sys.stdout. Based on src code in trainer.py on line 55, i noticed that it was not written to any other stream besides stdout. Is this correct?
Hey @joshbronko, if you have the training job id, you can pull the training logs from `/api/v1/classifier/logs/${training_job_id}`
@arun perfect, i was able to pull that data. thank you
on the note of the trainer.py file itself. is there a way to modify it for a particular model. Add additional log stream hanlders, etc
What are you trying to do? And which trainer.py file are you referring to?

Would like to send the log stream to a ELK stack to analyze data from the epoch themselves. Unless this already exisist somewhere. I was looking at the trainer.py that is located in the artifacts but would think it gets picked up from another location to copy to a temp stucture to execute

Interesting, I didn't realize we include trainer.py in the artifact. I would recommend not modifying those py files, they're no longer used for model training at that point.

What kinds of data are you collecting to analyze? This isn't really a product feature at the moment, although on certain environments we export metrics to W&B (cc @Rafal)

Just started this week and noticing there isnt an easy was to see when the epoch starts to get to a confidence/loss level that is worth moving towards without looking at the logs. The concept would be, ingest in the logs into an elk / db to do a quick analysis on where the breaking point is to get good results. i can easily pull the data from the api as i can see and then ingest that into a simple graph to show when the tipping point was per field

Hi @joshbronko
do you want to get the logs from actual model training? or you are doing inference only?
Both would be ideal. Constant visual feedback loop

ok
we actually have it on our ML Studio backlog to implement some dashboards to track losses, field metrics over epochs, etc. @lydia do you have a rough idea when we could start working on that?
as an interim solution, we might save in the model artifacts some additional logs — i.e. in tensorboard format

Hey! It’s not a high priority item at the moment. Our current focus for Q1/H1 is mostly on *stability* and *improving usability for less technical users*. This feature seems more geared towards power users / data scientists. Happy to get your perspective on that @joshbronko

I think the less technical users would be interested to understand how their models working. If a new user has to go into the logs to determine what hyperparams should be set to get good results or how the inference is being done by click by click on the results
Would love to catch up offline on some of the items i have noticed being brand new into the platform
